# Filtering
We often only want to look at specific parts of the data. To be able to do so we can filter the data in a few ways.
## Masks
We can use conditions which will return a Series of whether the column matches or doesn"t match the condition. This boolean Series, a so called filter mask can then be applied to the dataframe to only have the rows that are True (or False if we want that).

<!--- WARNING: THIS FILE WAS AUTOGENERATED! DO NOT EDIT! Instead, edit the notebook w/the location & name as this file.-->


```python
import pandas as pd

df_cars = pd.read_csv("data/cars.csv", sep=";", skiprows=[1])
```


```python
mask = df_cars["Cylinders"] == "4"
mask
```

<CodeOutputBlock lang="python">




    0      False
    1      False
    2      False
    3      False
    4      False
           ...  
    401    False
    402    False
    403    False
    404    False
    405    False
    Name: Cylinders, Length: 406, dtype: bool



</CodeOutputBlock>


```python
df_cars[mask]
```
    
<HTMLOutputBlock >




```html
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {

    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">

    <tr style="text-align: right;">

```



</HTMLOutputBlock>


```python
df_cars[df_cars["Cylinders"] == "4"]  # all at once
```
    
<HTMLOutputBlock >




```html
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {

    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th></th>
      <th>Car</th>
      <th>MPG</th>
      <th>Cylinders</th>
      <th>Displacement</th>
      <th>Horsepower</th>
      <th>Weight</th>
      <th>Acceleration</th>

```



</HTMLOutputBlock>

Conditions can also be combined with & as `and`, and | as `or`.


```python
df_cars[(df_cars["Cylinders"] == "4") & (df_cars["MPG"] == "24.0")]
```
    
<HTMLOutputBlock >




```html
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th></th>
      <th>Car</th>
      <th>MPG</th>
      <th>Cylinders</th>
      <th>Displacement</th>
      <th>Horsepower</th>
      <th>Weight</th>
      <th>Acceleration</th>
      <th>Model</th>
      <th>Origin</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
```



</HTMLOutputBlock>


```python
df_cars[(df_cars["MPG"] == "4") | (df_cars["MPG"] == "24.0")]
```
    
<HTMLOutputBlock >




```html
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {

    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th></th>
      <th>Car</th>
      <th>MPG</th>
      <th>Cylinders</th>
      <th>Displacement</th>
      <th>Horsepower</th>
      <th>Weight</th>
      <th>Acceleration</th>
      <th>Model</th>
      <th>Origin</th>

```



</HTMLOutputBlock>

## Isin
We can check to see if certain values are in a list.


```python
mpgs = ["24.0", "25.0", "30.0"]
df_cars[df_cars["MPG"].isin(mpgs)]
```
    
<HTMLOutputBlock >




```html
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th></th>
      <th>Car</th>
      <th>MPG</th>
      <th>Cylinders</th>
      <th>Displacement</th>
      <th>Horsepower</th>
      <th>Weight</th>
      <th>Acceleration</th>
      <th>Model</th>
      <th>Origin</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
```



</HTMLOutputBlock>

## Str accessor
The functions and methods under the str accessor provide flexible ways to filter rows based on strings.


```python
df_cars[df_cars["Car"].str.startswith("Toyota")]
```

```python
df_cars[df_cars["Car"].str.contains("Corolla")]
```

```html
      <td>16.9</td>
      <td>82</td>
      <td>Japan</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
```



</HTMLOutputBlock>

## Tilde
The tilde operator is used for “not” logic in filtering. If we add the tilde operator before the filter expression, the rows that do not fit the condition are returned.


```python
df_cars[~df_cars["Car"].str.contains("Corolla")]
```
    
<HTMLOutputBlock >




```html
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>

  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
```

```python
df_cars[~df_cars["MPG"].isin(mpgs)]
```
